Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the home loan statement spread out before me, numbers blurring as I tried to focus. My son’s school fees were due soon, and the bank’s deadline for the next payment loomed over me like a storm cloud. As a mother, I knew I had to keep our home secure, to make sure my children never felt the uncertainty I did now. But my phone buzzed, and Sister Maria’s voice trembled on the other end—“The mayor needs us. The hurricane’s left so many with nothing. They’re asking for you to lead the relief effort.” My heart twisted. As a nun, I was called to serve, to put the needs of the suffering above my own. The community expected me to be there, to give my time, my energy, my compassion. But every hour spent away from work was an hour I couldn’t earn for my family. I felt torn in two, the weight of both worlds pressing down, each demanding more than I had to give.
